awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Information-Theoretic Foundations of Community Detection and Graphical Channels
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of this project is to establish the fundamental limits of community detection. In virtually all applications dealing with networks and large data sets, one wishes to extract sub-groups of data points that are similar, i.e., communities. While community detection techniques are expanding daily with practical successes, relatively less attention has been paid to the fundamental limits, and consequently to where current algorithms stand. By establishing the fundamental limits of community detection, this project offers a novel take on community detection algorithms, and expands information theory in a prominent area where it can naturally flourish. The project will work with real data sets from social and biological networks. In particular, it develops a new initiative to extract communities in Hi-C genomic data, contributing to unveil the 3D folding structure of DNA.

The project will focus in particular on the stochastic block model, a canonical model for community detection. The investigator's recent work leverages information theory to provide the first necessary and sufficient conditions for exact recovery in the stochastic block model, and an efficient algorithm achieving the limit. This opens the door to a new perspective on community detection, which is developed in this project by casting community detection as unorthodox error-control coding problems. In this context, new types of f-divergences are expected to play a key role, analogous to the Kullback-Leibler divergence in Shannon's channel coding theorem, while other weaker recovery requirements may rely on unorthodox broadcasting problems, graph entropic inequalities, and information-estimation problems. This makes the study of community detection a rich area connecting information theory, machine learning and networks; less focused on ergodic results; and more interlaced with graph theory and spectral analysis. In particular, this project will show how these problems, as well as more general low-rank approximation problems, can be studied under the novel and unifying theme of graphical channels.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal demonstrates how information-theoretic techniques and concepts can be brought to bear on community detection problems in fruitful ways. Machine learning has been already successful in providing tools and practical algorithms for extracting information in networks such as in social sciences, biology, computer vision or natural language processing. Despite this practical success, relatively less attention has been paid to fundamental limits of information extraction, and thus to where the current algorithms stand. This is where information theory and this proposal plays a role.

The objectives of the proposals were to break down the analysis on community detection on (i) different types of generative models, (ii) different types of recovery requirements. More specifically, there were 4 thrusts:

1. Exact recovery (where communities need to be entirely recovered): a major outcome of the proposal shows that exact recovery in the stochastic block model (SBM) admits a form of `channel coding theorem', where a new f-divergence governs the fundamental limit.

This was first shown for the two-community symmetric SBM in:

  • E. Abbe, A. Bandeira, G. Hall, Exact recovery in the stochastic block model, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, 62(1):471-487, 2016. Best Paper Award for IEEE Transactions on Information Theory in 2016.

This phenomenon was shown to extend much beyond this simple model, holding for general block models with a fundamental limit governed by an f-divergence that bridges the Chernoff and Hellinger divergence:

  • E. Abbe, C. Sandon, Community detection in SBM: fundamental limits and efficient algorithms for recovery, Proc. of IEEE Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS), Berkeley, 2015. 

Both works have also devised efficient algorithms that succeed down to the information-theoretic limit, thus the proposal outcome established and achieved the fundamental limit.  

2. Weak recovery (where communities need to be recovered in the weakest non-trivial sense). In the other extreme of exact recovery, the proposal investigated when the community signals are too weak to be even detected. This is important in particular to identify regimes where community detection algorithms are doomed to produce artifacts. The fundamental limits for weak recovery had only been understood in prior works for the two-community symmetric SBM. However, in contrast to exact recovery, major behavioral changes were expected to take place for weak recovery under more than 2 communities. In particular, it was conjectured that starting from 4 communities, information-theoretic methods could go beyond the so-called KS threshold, expected to be the fundamental limit for efficient algorithms. This implies that there is a gap between what can be achieved with efficient (i.e., polynomial time) versus non-efficient (i.e., information-theoretic) methods.

In a major outcome of the proposal, we are able to prove this conjecture for the general SBM:

  • E. Abbe, C. Sandon, Proof of the achievability conjectures for the general stochastic block model. Communications on Pure and Applied Mathematics, 2017.

3. Partial recovery. Between weak and exact recovery, how much can we hope to recover about the communities? In a major outcome of the proposal, we were able to almost fully characterize the partial recovery problem:

  • E. Abbe, E. Cornacchia, Y. Gu, Y. Polyanskiy, Stochastic block model entropy and broadcasting on trees with survey, In proceeding of the Conference on Learning Theory (COLT). COLT?21 Best Student Paper Award

4. Unifying and beyond. Projects 1-2-3 tackled a rich class of block models and recovery requirements. However, we wish to have an understanding of community detection that goes beyond a case-by-case treatment. Moreover, communities may not always be defined by a finite number of membership classes, such as in graphons, and graphs may not always have the mean field properties of SBMs, such as in geometric block models. Is there a unified and robust theory of community detection?

In two major outcomes of the proposal, we established community detection tradeoffs as in the previous thrusts for models that depart significantly from the SBM, allowing for geometric constraints on the community memberships:

  • E. Abbe, L. Massoulie, A. Montanari, A. Sly, N. Srivastava. Group synchronization on grids. Mathematical Statistics and Learning (MSL), 2018.

We also generalized the notion of KS threshold for graphons, showing further that the generalized threshold was achievable by efficient algorithms and settling a problem left open in the context sparse graphons:

  • E. Abbe, S. Li, A. Sly, Learning sparse graphons and the generalized Kesten-Stigum Threshold (submitted).

Finally, a major outcome of the proposal has been to unify the newly developed theory for community detection in a monograph:

  • E. Abbe, Community detection and Stochastic block models Foundations and Trends, Now Publisher, 2018.

The monograph has become a major reference in the field, broadly referred to, with the fundamental limit line of work connected to various areas of mathematics and computer science, and with efficient algorithms developed and used in a variety of applications of machine learning and network science.
